sn41.8:1.1: This is Mahāvīra, who according to Buddhist accounts died before the Buddha, so if this is a genuine encounter it must have been while the Buddha was still alive. The whole story seems a little parodic, although Citta’s eagerness to trounce Mahāvīra is very much in character.
sn41.8:2.4: It is not easy to trace details of early Jain meditation. For the most part they focused on austerities and self-mortification, which the Buddha found to be counterproductive to deep meditation (MN 36:33.2).
sn41.8:3.3: Citta uses the same technique employed so often by the Buddha: start by finding something in common. The superiority of knowledge over faith is a philosophical point in which Buddhism and Jainism are in agreement.
sn41.8:5.9: This passage echoes AN 10.27:9.2, where the Buddha recommends asking this series of questions of a sectarian in order to stump them. | The grammar of these questions is peculiar, for which see Bodhi’s note 323 in Connected Discourses and 2003 in Numerical Discourses.
sn41.8:5.19: This whole passage is, I think, Pali for: “You are so pwned. Delete your account.”
